STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 28, 2025
Michelle Seigo
IONIA COUNTY DHHS
920 E LINCOLN AVE,
IONIA, MI, 48846-1393
RE: License#: CP340201198
Dear Michelle Seigo:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on March 27, 2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 2024-
6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
(231) 342-3721
enclosure

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
• (4) An agency shall document placement
specifications consistent with the information
contained in the reevaluation. The placement
specifications must include all the following:
• (a) The age, number, SOGIE, race, ethnic
background, and characteristics of
children preferred by the applicants.
Three of three foster home files reviewed did not document preferred placement
specifications regarding SOGIE.
CPA Rule 400.12415 Unusual incident reporting policy
• (1) An agency must adhere to the following
incident reporting protocols:
• (a) Immediately notify the child's parents;
the department licensing authority; the
lawyer guardian ad litem and court, as
applicable; the department; and the foster

child's parents, if any of the following
occurs:
• (iv) Any medical and mental illness
or condition that results in
treatment at a hospital emergency
room or inpatient hospitalization of
a foster child.
One of three foster care files reviewed did not have documentation an incident
report was completed when a foster youth went to the emergency room.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with
all the following information before the
placement or replacement of a child:
• (b) Child's date of birth.
Two of three foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided youth's date of birth prior to placement.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with
all the following information before the
placement or replacement of a child:
• (f) All known behaviors of the child.
Two of three foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided youth's known behaviors.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with
all the following information before the
placement or replacement of a child:
• (c) Available known information about the
child's health.

Two of three foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided youth's known health information.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with
all the following information before the
placement or replacement of a child:
• (d) Any known history of abuse or neglect
of the child.
Two of three foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided youth's known abuse/neglect history.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with
all the following information before the
placement or replacement of a child:
• (e) All known emotional and
psychological factors relating to the care
of the child.
Two of three foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided youth's known emotional and psychological factors.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with
all the following information before the
placement or replacement of a child:
• (g) Circumstances necessitating
placement or replacement of the child.
Two of three foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided circumstances necessitating placement.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information

• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with
all the following information before the
placement or replacement of a child:
• (h) Any other known information to enable
the foster parent to provide a stable, safe,
and healthy environment for the foster
child and the foster family, including
information about siblings who do not
reside in the foster home as provided in
federal law.
Two of three foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided any known information to enable foster parent to provide a safe,
stable, and healthy environment for the foster child and the foster family including
any sibling information.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with
all the following information before the
placement or replacement of a child:
• (a) Child's name.
Two of three foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided youth's name prior to placement.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Based on audit findings it is recommended appropriate checklists or
monitoring tool are updated to include missing requirements.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• There was no consultation requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.

There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
agency interim inspection was completed on 3/19/2024 and the CAP was
approved on 5/8/2024. The agency was cited for 6 violations, none of which were
repeated this year. In 2023, 8 violations were established, none of which were
repeated this year.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator assessment was received and reviewed. The assessment
noted the agency struggled with staff turnover as well as challenges related to
finding appropriate placements for youth with difficult behaviors. However, the CA
noted the previous year CAP was largely effective. The process of development
the CAP together with staff and utilizing the checklist was effective. In addition, the
agency has held regularly scheduled quarterly meetings regarding the CAP
throughout the review period that has also been helpful. The assessment noted
the agency will continue working on areas of follow through but have seen
improvement and the CA believes the agency will continue to improve.
Financial Overview
N/A
Staff and Youth Interviews
Interviews were conducted with two staff via telephone. Staff reported feeling
supported by the agency. Supervisors are available to assist as needed. Staff did
not report any concerns or areas of need.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care and licensing services. All files were stored securely and
there is a cross shredder for CHRI.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
Safety Alert #1: Unlicensed relative caregiver refused to contact CPA Analyst for
home visit, therefore safety of the child placed as well as the home could not be
verified.
Resolution: The agency contacted unlicensed relative caregiver, who responded
immediately. An announced home visit was completed on the same day by foster
care staff. A safety plan was completed and included keeping all sharp objects and
medications in lock boxes, as well as caregiver reaching out to appropriate
individuals if the child does harm to herself or others and utilizing the Forest View

safety plan that was previously developed.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
________3/28/2025_____________________________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
March 28, 2025
